paper_title.en: Three-fiber based diffuse reflectance measurement technique for non-destructive measurement of sugar content in fruit and its verification by electronically tuned Ti: Sapphire laser in the wavelength range 900 - 1070nm

description.en: Sugar content is one of the most important attributes in determining the quality of fruits such as apples. Sugar content is normally measured using destructive juice extraction methods, such as Brix refractometry. Recently, several nondestructive methods of determining sugar content in fruit using a spectrometer have been reported1-4. Kawano et al.2 showed that the near-infrared reflectance in the wavelength between 800nm and 1000nm could be used to determine the sugar content in peaches. They analyzed the reflection spectrum by means of multiple regression analysis, and consequently found that sugar content, measured with Brix refract meter, was related to second differential of absorbance with respect to 906, 870, 878, and 889nm with a standard error in the prediction of 0.51Brix. The above current technique is known as the near infrared spectroscopy. In the near infrared spectroscopy, the calibration curve can be easily obtained from multivariate spectrum analysis and the sample component values, even if there is no physical knowledge of the object being measured. However, the current spectroscopic method, above, requires spectrometer using diffraction gratings and a white light source. Thus, the instrumentation required is not readily portable to an orchard situation. We have recently proposed the three-fiber based diffuse reflectance measurement method for the sugar content of fruit that used only three near-infrared lasers, but no diffraction grating5. A parameter, γ, which is independent of the optical path length is considered, such that γ= In (Ri/Rk)/ln (Rj/Rk). where the values of reflectance Ri, j, k represent the ratio of values of diffuse light power reaching to two receiving fibers, corresponding to different wavelengths λi, j, k. Based on a simulation using a diffusion model, it was found that there are optimum combinations of the three wavelengths for which the correlation between the parameter γ and the sugar content of fruit becomes sufficiently high. The experimental test, employing three near infrared laser diodes, clearly demonstrated the usefulness of the proposed method. In the present work, a verification of the proposed method has been executed by employing an electronically tuned Ti: sapphire laser6 as a light source. The laser wavelengths can be continuously tuned by adjustment of the rf to an intracavity acousto-optic tunable filter, under computer control, in the wavelength range 900-1070nm. The laser generates 50-ns or shorter pulses at a repetition rate of 5kHz, at an average power of about 70mW, which are directed onto the fruit through the 1-mm diam emitter fiber in contact with the fruit skin. The diffusive reflected illumination is collected at distances of 10mm, 17mm from the source, using 1-mm diam receiving fibers in contact with the skin. These signals are led to InGaAS photodiodes with lock-in-amplifiers and converted digitally by a 16bit A/D converter. An unpeeled apple was used as a measurement sample. A digital refractometer was used to measure the Brix value of fruit juice extracted from the measured sample. The parameter γ can be approximately expressed for a model of an apple as follows: γ= (αi μa, j - αkμ a,k) / (αjμa, j - α kμa, k), (1) where αi=[3(1+μ a, i/μ′s, i)]0.5, μ′ s, i is the reduced scattering coefficient, μa, i is the absorption coefficient, and the subscript i, j, k indicates the wavelength λi, j, k. If it is assumed that the reduced scattering coefficient, μ′s, i, is independent of the wavelength, and μ′s, i ≫ μa, i, Eq. (1) can be simplified to: γ= (μ0.5 aGlu, i - μ0.5 aGlu, k) / (μ0.5 aGlu,j - μ0.5 aGlu, k), (2) where μaGiu, i is the absorption coefficient of a glucose solution at the wavelength λi, which has the same as sugar content and the temperature of the measured apple. Figure 1 compares the measurement results of γ as a function of the illumination wavelength λj with the diffusion model expressed by Eq. (2), in which other wavelengths λi, λk are set to 1060nm and 900nm, respectively. The theoretical value from Eq. (2) and measured results correspond well. Thus it can be said that the parameter γis independent of both the optical path length and the reduced scattering coefficient μ′s, i. The reflectance, Ri, changed with the epidermal conditions of the fruit at the two places where the receiving fibers were positioned. The above results show that y is independent of the reflectance changes due to surface conditions of the apple. Next we examine a linear correlation between the value of γ and the fruit sugar content. Experimental values of γ were obtained with 50 apples, and theoretical values of γwere calculated from Eq. (2) by using absorption coefficients of glucose solutions with several glucose contents. Shown in Fig. 2 are the theoretical and the experimental signal-to-noise ratios, η =β2/σ2, as a function of the wavelength λj, where β is the inclination of the regression line of the relationship between γ and the fruit sugar content, and σ is the standard deviation of the regression error. Other wavelengths λi, λk are set to 1060nm and 900nm, respectively. The measured data are in good agreement with theoretical values within the range 900 - 946nm. On the other hand, there was a significant departure from the theoretical value within the range 950nm - 1040nm. For the experimental results, 77 becomes 3.5 or greater in the wavelength range 927 -946nm, indicating that the estimated error in the sugar content is (1/3.5) 0.5 = 0.53Brix or less. It has been verified that the accuracy of measurement of fruit sugar content using only three near-infrared wavelengths is a practical proposition, although the wavelength range, suitable for measurement, is narrower than the range theoretically predicted. Further consideration of the reason for the significant deviation of η from the theoretical value in the wavelength range above 950nm is necessary. The three-fiber based diffuse reflectance measurement technique proposed here is effective, not only for the measurement of the fruit sugar content, but also of the biological components in human tissues in a noninvasive manner. In particular, it is thought that the change of the optical path length, occasioned by the swelling and shrinkage of the blood vessel in the living body, can be corrected by means of the proposed technique. © 2005 IEEE.

paper_title.en: Development of Nondestructive Measurement Technique for Fruits Sugar Content with Near-Infrared Laser Diodes Operating at Three Different Wavelengths
New measurement technique that uses three near infrared diode lasers for non-destructive evaluation of sugar content in fruits

description.en: For non-destructive evaluation of sugar content in fruits, it has been proposed new measurement technique that uses three near infrared diode lasers. The reflectance R-i at the wavelength lambda(i) is defined by the ratio of two diffuse light powers reaching the two receiving fibers that were positioned at the different distance from a light emitting fiber. The value gamma = In (R-i/R-k)/ln (R-j/R-k) reaches the value that doesn't approximately depend on optical path length. As a simulation result of,gamma to a modeled apple, it was found that there are some combinations of three near-infrared wavelengths in which the correlation of gamma and the sugar content of fruits raise. We actually evaluated the sugar content of apples by the use of three diode lasers 911nm, 936nm and 1055nm. As a result, it was confirmed that the measurement technique proposed here was usefulness.

publication_name.en: Light-Emitting Diodes: Research, Manufacturing, and Applications IX

paper_title.en: Position Sensing System Using Point Source of Light for Curved Micro-tunneling.
Position sensing system using laser for curved tunneling

description.en: Curved micro-tunneling using small conduit pipes with diameters of Im or less is recently applied in many construction sites. We have come up with a new position sensing system to pinpoint the head of the first pipe even when it cannot be seen directly from the base position. It differs from the traditional method of using the collimated laser beam, in that a diode laser with a large divergence is used as the point source of light. The direction of the point source of light is detected by using an objective lens and CCD camera. To apply this method to the position detection of the first pipe, the structure of the sensing unit and its detection accuracy were examined and the following results were obtained. (1) The structure using a polarized beam splitter can suppress error led by rotating the sensing unit. (2) Through simulation and some field tests, 20 seconds or less detection accuracy of direction angle was achieved.

publication_name.en: HIGH-POWER LASERS IN CIVIL ENGINEERING AND ARCHITECTURE
